summary: A series of letters and memoranda from the Interlochen Center for the Arts to Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, documenting Epstein's significant financial donations for the construction and endowment of a scholarship lodge, subsequent annual gifts, and his involvement with the institution. The documents show a philanthropic relationship and detail the logistics of the lodge construction and use.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Primary donor to Interlochen Center for the Arts, funding the construction of the 'Jeffrey E. Epstein Scholarship Lodge' and making multiple subsequent large financial contributions for scholarships and operations.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Correspondent and liaison for Jeffrey Epstein regarding the scholarship lodge, involved in reviewing furniture packages and receiving communications about the lodge.

persons.name: Karen Sargent
persons.context: Noted architect and Interlochen alumna hired to modify the lodge blueprints to incorporate wheelchair and handicap accessibility.

persons.name: Dean Boal
persons.context: Interlochen administrator consulted on the lodge placement and later thanked Epstein for a contribution.

persons.name: James L. Tolley
persons.context: Chair of Interlochen's Board of Trustees who sent a formal letter of appreciation for Epstein's $200,000 gift for the lodge.

persons.name: Richard F. Odell
persons.context: President of Interlochen Center for the Arts who sent thank-you letters acknowledging Epstein's donations.

persons.name: Dr. Tuckerman
persons.context: Mentioned as having made a recent endowed gift in Jeffrey Epstein's honor.

persons.name: Dr. Luby
persons.context: Colleague referenced in a letter, whose term 'mensch' is borrowed to describe Epstein.

persons.name: Ed Downing
persons.context: Mentioned as working on the Summer Festival Concert Series.

persons.name: Itzhak Perlman
persons.context: Noted violinist scheduled to give a concert at Interlochen on August 7, 1994, mentioned as an event near Epstein's reserved lodge time.

connections.description: Maxwell acts as a liaison and point of contact for Epstein regarding the Interlochen scholarship lodge, reviewing plans and receiving communications on his behalf.

connections.person2: Interlochen Center for the Arts Staff
connections.description: Epstein is a major donor to the institution, funding a lodge and annual scholarships, leading to extensive correspondence and gratitude from administrators like Richard Odell and James Tolley.

events.title: Lodge Blueprint Planning
events.description: Interlochen informs an unnamed recipient about plans to build scholarship lodges, with architect Karen Sargent modifying blueprints for accessibility.

events.title: Acknowledgement of $200,000 Lodge Gift
events.description: Interlochen thanks Jeffrey Epstein for a $200,000 gift to build a new, handicapped-accessible scholarship lodge, detailing construction plans and naming rights.

events.title: Itzhak Perlman Concert
events.description: Itzhak Perlman is scheduled to give a concert at Interlochen, mentioned as a potential reason for Epstein to visit and use his reserved lodge time.

events.title: Epstein Lodge Ready for Use
events.description: Interlochen informs Ghislaine Maxwell that the Epstein Lodge is ready, an envelope was found during cleaning, and it has been reserved for Jeffrey Epstein's use.

events.title: World Youth Symphony Orchestra at Olympics
events.description: Interlochen's World Youth Symphony Orchestra performs at Symphony Hall in Atlanta as part of the Cultural Olympiad opening weekend, an event supported by Epstein's donations.

events.title: $50,000 Donation for Scholarships
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein sends a $50,000 check to Interlochen, specifying $5,000 be used for a scholarship for a student from South Africa.

locations: Interlochen Center for the Arts, P.O. Box 199, Interlochen, Michigan 49643-0199
The Villard House, 457 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10022
Frohlich lodge (area next to it on Interlochen campus)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein donated $200,000 to fund the construction of the 'Jeffrey E. Epstein Scholarship Lodge' at Interlochen Center for the Arts, the institution's first handicapped-accessible facility.
Epstein was granted personal use of the lodge for two weeks each year without affecting the tax deductibility of his gift.
Epstein made multiple subsequent annual donations to Interlochen, totaling at least $215,000 between 1994 and 1997, for scholarships, operations, and specific projects like the Olympic fund.
Ghislaine Maxwell was actively involved as a correspondent and liaison for Epstein regarding the lodge's furnishings and logistics.
The documents illustrate a sustained philanthropic relationship between Epstein and a prestigious arts institution, portraying him as a generous benefactor.
